Inference: High activation frequency indicates intensive interaction at that fixture
Description: Frequent proximity-based on/off events over a day suggest that this faucet or showerhead is used heavily, reflecting a high number of user interactions in that location.
short rationale: Heavy usage patterns expose occupant presence and frequency.

Inference: Sparse activation patterns imply low utilization or secondary role
Description: Very few proximity activations over long periods indicate that the fixture is rarely approached or that it plays a minor role in daily routines.
short rationale: Minimal presence signal with limited behavioral detail.

Inference: Consistent morning peaks reveal stable hygiene routines
Description: Clustering of proximity activations in early morning windows across many days indicates stable habits such as regular washing, brushing, or showering routines.
short rationale: Reveals stable daily hygiene schedule and timing.

Inference: Evening or late-night peaks point to end-of-day usage rituals
Description: When activations repeatedly cluster at night, it suggests routines like pre-sleep washing or late showers that are consistently initiated via proximity sensing.
short rationale: Shows end-of-day routines and sleep timing cues.

Inference: Activations during typical absence windows hint at unusual activity
Description: Proximity activations appearing during historically low-usage periods signal unexpected presence, schedule changes, or accidental sensor triggering.
short rationale: Highlights unexpected occupancy windows.

Inference: Weekend-dominant activation patterns indicate schedule-driven usage
Description: Higher activation counts on weekends compared to weekdays imply that users interact more with the fixture when they are off work or spending more time at home.
short rationale: Shows work/leisure schedule tendencies.

Inference: Day-of-week variation exposes different routine structures
Description: Distinct patterns (e.g., Monday and Friday peaks vs midweek lows) reflect weekly rhythms such as specific days with more intensive cleaning or showering.
short rationale: Maps weekly routine differences by day.

Inference: Short-duration activations suggest quick tasks or possible false triggers
Description: On–off pairs with very brief intervals indicate quick interactions like hand rinses or non-purposeful triggers caused by passing movement near the sensor.
short rationale: Indicates quick tasks or noise with low identifiability.

Inference: Long-duration activations reveal extended use sessions
Description: On–off intervals that stay open much longer than the typical median duration imply extended tasks such as longer showers or prolonged washing at that fixture.
short rationale: Signals long personal tasks at a location.

Inference: Burst-like activation sequences indicate clustered user presence
Description: Many activations in a short time window suggest a user staying near the fixture, performing repeated or multi-step tasks.
short rationale: Shows clustered presence and task intensity.

Inference: Increase in average activation duration signals changing habits
Description: A trend where on–off intervals grow longer over time suggests users are spending more time per interaction, possibly shifting to more elaborate use.
short rationale: Tracks habit shift toward longer sessions.

Inference: Decrease in activation duration implies more efficient or hurried use
Description: If average activation times shrink, it suggests users are performing shorter interactions, becoming more efficient or changing routines.
short rationale: Suggests efficiency changes with little identity risk.

Inference: Growing activation count over time indicates rising fixture importance
Description: A steady rise in daily or weekly proximity activations suggests this fixture is becoming more central to occupants’ routines or overall traffic has increased.
short rationale: Shows rising fixture centrality reflecting behavioral change.

Inference: Drop in activation count flags possible disuse or alternative behaviors
Description: A noticeable decline in proximity activations after a stable period indicates that users may be avoiding that fixture, using another one, or occupying the space less.
short rationale: Indicates avoidance or absence trends over time.

Inference: Sudden activation spikes mark special events or occupancy surges
Description: A one-off day with a very high number of proximity activations compared to baseline suggests temporary conditions such as guests or atypical intensive use.
short rationale: Highlights unusual occupancy or guest events.

Inference: Extended periods with zero activations indicate vacancy or sensor failure
Description: Long continuous gaps with no proximity-based on/off events may denote prolonged absence or potential malfunction of the proximity sensor or logging system.
short rationale: Reveals prolonged absence periods or unattended space.

Inference: Irregular on/off pairing points to logging or control anomalies
Description: Missing or mismatched on/off events suggest anomalies in event logging, communication glitches, or control logic issues at the sensor.
short rationale: Primarily system issues with minimal personal data.

Inference: Time-of-day shift in activation peaks reveals changing daily schedules
Description: If the primary activation peak gradually moves from one time window to another, it indicates a shift in occupants’ routine timing.
short rationale: Shows when routines move, exposing schedule adjustments.

Inference: Multimodal daily patterns indicate diverse usage scenarios
Description: Days showing two or more distinct activation peaks suggest that the same fixture supports multiple routine types in different parts of the day.
short rationale: Multiple peaks outline different routine types.

Inference: High activation frequency with very short durations suggests sensor sensitivity issues
Description: When there are many extremely brief activations, it may indicate that the proximity sensor is overly sensitive or frequently triggered by pass-by motion.
short rationale: Likely sensor noise with limited behavioral insight.

Inference: Stable activation rhythm indicates mature, predictable behavior
Description: When daily activation counts and timing remain highly consistent over long periods, it suggests well-established routines with little change in usage.
short rationale: Predictable timing makes occupants’ schedule highly inferable.

Inference: Growing variability in activation times signals lifestyle or schedule changes
Description: If the distribution of activation times becomes more scattered across the day, it implies less structured routines or irregular occupancy.
short rationale: Shows lifestyle volatility without precise identity.

Inference: Fixture-level comparison of activation density reveals primary vs secondary points of use
Description: Comparing total proximity activations across fixtures shows which ones function as primary interaction points versus secondary or backup ones.
short rationale: Identifies preferred fixtures but coarse on timing.

Inference: Activation clusters overlapping among multiple fixtures imply concurrent usage zones
Description: If several fixtures show overlapping activation bursts in the same time window, it suggests multiple occupants using different faucets or showerheads simultaneously.
short rationale: Exposes co-occupancy windows and spatial coordination.

Inference: Shift from clustered to isolated activations indicates reduced multi-step tasks
Description: Transition from many back-to-back activations toward more isolated single activations suggests a change from complex tasks to simpler, one-off interactions.
short rationale: Shows task complexity shift with limited personal detail.

Inference: Consistent activation just after specific clock times indicates habit-driven starts
Description: Repeated activations at nearly the same time highlight habitually timed actions such as a user’s precise routine start.
short rationale: Precise clock-linked behavior strongly identifies individual routines.

Inference: Night-time activation emergence after prior absence hints at new occupancy pattern
Description: If night-time activations start appearing in a fixture that previously had none, it suggests new behavior such as shift work, changed sleep patterns, or additional usage.
short rationale: Reveals new night presence patterns affecting security and privacy.

Inference: Seasonal shifts in activation timing reflect daylight or routine changes
Description: Over months, if peak activation windows drift relative to clock time, that pattern aligns with seasonal adjustments in daily routines.
short rationale: Coarse seasonal shifts with limited identifiability.

Inference: High activation counts with moderate durations suggest many short but purposeful tasks
Description: When activation numbers are high but average duration stays moderate, it reflects many distinct but meaningful interactions like repeated handwashing.
short rationale: Indicates frequent tasks without fine-grained schedule exposure.

Inference: Low activation count with very long durations indicates infrequent but intensive use
Description: A pattern of few daily activations, each lasting much longer than typical, suggests the fixture is used rarely but for substantial continuous tasks.
short rationale: Reveals occasional long sessions with modest schedule detail.
